node.html:
A self-initiated internal tool I created to assist support staff, management, and developers at IAS to give an overhead view of all our Marketplace clients and their inventory, settings, and events, test apis, and more.

I am currently in the process of adding TypeScript.

A mobile app I created for my wife and I when we were doing the same workout program. The app allows you to set your maxes and then calculates the weights for each workout.

It was also an opportunity for me to play with custom animations using Lottie, as well as parallax page transitions.

A proof of concept I created for a friend of mine who has an online community of strength trainers. This digital record board mimics the physical record boards he had when he owned a brick and mortar gym.

It is web based but 100% responsive and looks great on mobile devices as well.

I built this app years ago to help us decide on a new city. It fetches and scrapes data from Best Places and Area Vibes and then displays it in a simplified format.

The app is no longer functional, but I have left it up for posterity and made it work with Austin, TX.

A fun spin-off of Your Places, this app allows you to rank states by several different metrics and then see how they stack up against each other.

Like many of my apps this started as a node cli before I deployed a web version.

Online version of my resume I made to stand-out. It's handy and responsive, but when converting it to pdf the document is not scannable by ATS software!

I have since made a pdf version that is scannable, but left this site up to show my work.
I needed an excuse to try Svelte so I made a super simple photo gallery for my mom's figurines.

My daughter wanted to memorize the bible verses she was given in VBS a couple summers ago and I made this simple little app to help her. It's web based but meant to be viewed on a phone and plays her voice and her mother's voice so she can hear it as well as read it.
100% credit goes to Brittany Chiang for designing this site. I just took her project and made it my own with some tweaks. This was my first experience with Gatsby and GraphQL besides Udemy tutorials.
